text: God damn malt liquors. Aroma is rubbing alcohol, slight tartness, metallic, corn, atrocious. Appearance is amber golden, slight haze, white head. Taste is perfume, corn, rubbing alcohol, metallic, not great. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, perfume and maybe slight hop aftertaste. Overall, for the style, this is one of the better ones, despite the aroma.

Winter is coming....and yet it seem a late crop of summer pilseners are appearing en mass upon the shelves at beer world.. This one had a price that could not be ignored. The old adage of you get what you pay for also echoed softly in my mind at the time of purchase. You pessimists out there will not be disapointed. This is total crap reminiscent of the over sweet with tarter finish Baltika swill. UDBeernut will love this.
Semi clear orange-ish amber color and a khaku head with good retention. Decent lacing. Taste is pure alcoholic paint thinner. Disgusting. Drain pour. 8.0 ABV is obvious.

Shared 11.2 oz. bottle. Pours a clear pale gold with a white head. Aroma and taste of light malt, floral elements, grass, hints of apple juice and white wine. maybe some pear? Musty. Finish is warming, sweet and malty. Its really weird. Cant say Ive had anything quite like this. And in this case, thats not a good thing.

Aroma: odd, fruity aroma with a strong backbone of corn and rotting apple juice; Appearance: pale straw, clear, with white head that dissipates fairly quickly; Taste: not quite as bad as it smells but almost; sickly sweet with apple juice finish; Palate: light bodied with medium, sweet finish; Overall: Yuck. A drain pour.

Taste: crisp, semi sweet malt, herbal notes.
Slight perfume nose. Pale gold semi clear, with a tight bubbled head small lace. Lite body. Delicate sweet version of a lager.
33cl bottle 8.8%abv. Fusel and grain aroma. Oxidized some fruit aroma. Flavor is boozy and oxidized, tastes like sherry, gross. Like a really bad HG malt.

How: Bottle.
Where: Sunrise Sea Food Restaurant, Unawatuna Sri Lanka.
Appearance: Dark golden colour with a large white head.
Aroma: Malt, fruit, corn, alcohol.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Sweet malt, alcohol, corn.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught. Bright yellow with small frothy white head, doughy aroma, low carbonation, sweetish malt taste, thin body, abrupt finish with little hops effect. Not a great brew.
shared bottle poured into a tumbler..straw yellow with a fluffy white head..aroma of grass,malts,hops,earth...malty,hoppy..pilsners not really my style.

Good label and heavy longneck. Misty darkish gold, stiff white head. Malty wet straw aroma. Sweet, strong, reminds me of Soviet bloc strong lagers. Warming. Malty, astringent, lightly fruity finish. ABC Liquors, Betton.

Definitely filtered. Very smooth body, crisp taste, sweet flavor immediately, cotton candy, very mild hop bitterness, good carbonation. Alcohol is present for sure. Would be a nice warm weather beer as it is refreshing, but not watered down.
Pours a clear golden color. Aroma and taste are malty, grainy, and some lemon.
Bought a can on Langkawi, Malaysia. 'Exotic' lager, little bit to exotisch and strong for my taste...
11.2oz bottle. Pours a clear gold with a small white head. Aromas of grape candy. Taste is sweet. Flavors of grape drank, cotton candy. Corn. Finish is sweet and syrupy. Pretty bad.

330 ml bottle into lager glass, no bottle dating. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy bright orange/copper color with a 1 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big lemon, orange peel, pear, apple, honey, bread, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Mediocre aromas with notes of big fruity/earthy yeast and moderate pale malt sweetness; with poor balance. Way too much fruitiness in the nose. Taste of lemon, orange peel, pear, apple, honey, bread, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. No bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, orange peel, pear, apple, honey, bread, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Very mediocre flavor profile with poor balance of pale malt sweetness and some significant fruity yeast ester flavors; with some moderate cloying sweetness after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a moderately creamy and fairly slick mouthfeel that is a bit rough. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is a really poor strong lager style. Just all around unbalanced and overly fruity in flavor; and pretty difficult to drink with the odd/rough mouthfeel. This tasted really similar to apple cider with all the fruitiness. It was not a drain pour, but it was close.

Undrinkable strong beer with a cloying port-like sweetness from the start and into the aftertaste. Strong alcoholic presence. Abhorrent.

Based on the other reviews on here I wonder if the one I got was bad. It wasnt just bad. It was completely impossible to gulp down.
Bottle - Pours a clear yellow with fairly large, creamy head. Sweet biscuity aroma. Taste starts ok then goes to chemical astringent. Shame.

"not nearly up to par with the stout, but i wasnt expecting it to be. pleasant semi-sweet fruity aroma. taste is similar, with light grassy hops. full bodied, especially given the fizzy cloudy yellow look. fruit and a bit of alcohol in the finish."

12 oz. can I think I grabbed this at Dutchs (from notes). Pours a very pale yellow color with a medium sized quickly fading fizzy white head. The aroma and flavor have pilsner and pale malts, some sweetness, straw, grainy notes, apple. Light bodied, boring, general pale lager/pils.
Bottle. Cream. herbal lemon, and barley malt aroma. Golden yellow with small head. Sweet lemon, milky caramel malt and mildly bitter herbal and alcohol flavor. Not bad.

Bottle: (labeled as 8.8 %)
Pours nearly clear, pale gold with a creamy white head.
Slightly sour white grape, grain malt aroma.
Lemon, honey, pils taste.....very sweet..
This is really VERY good...seriously.......
I hope this is the right rate, the Lion Strong clocks in at 8.8, but the labeling indicates this one...both are SPL/IPs...well, it was a great little beer, Ill take an admin slap for it if Im wrong!

Rated on 1-17-2011 (Bottle) This beers appearance is a small white head that mostly diminishes, transparent yellow golden tint, fizzy carbonation, and a fair amount of lacing. The aroma is malty, grainy, corn, floral, sweet, fruity, spicy, and alcohol. The taste is sweet, crisp, malt, floral hops, corn, grainy, some alcohol, and a bit harsh. The mouth feel is lively and this beer is medium bodied. I did not like the harshness with the flavor of this beer and it made it difficult for me to drink this beer let alone enjoy it.
At Hops and Props Beer Fest. Not sure why no one likes this. The aroma is caramel sweet, cereal grain, grassy. The flavor follows. The finish is spicy noble hops. Good overall.

Oh my god, this is one of the all time worst beers! I poured it a bit too cold which should have benefitted this, but its quality shown thru. The beer reeked of sweet solvents. One taste and I almost retched; had to dump it and wash my mouth out. If you want somebody to leave your party, give them this beer.
Light caramel, grain, apples and lemongrass. A musky aftertaste detracts from this one. Alcohol is well masked. More flavorful than your typical lager, but not as crisp.
12oz bottle, light golden orange in appearance. Scent of sour grains. Taste is sour apple, yeast and grain, a bit sweet. Alcohol pretty noticeable as well.

Bottle courtesy of Ken1. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, sour fruit, yeasty and a little alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish with notes of alcohol. 160813
A sweet fruity aroma, and a sweet fruity flavor with a creamy warm alcoholic mouthfeel. Color is amber with a white head.

12 oz. can shared by DrSilverworm- thanks, Chris! Looks almost like champagne on the pour, a very pale yellow with big bubbles and a quick fizzy white head. Notes of pils and pale malts, sugar, straw, grape, and apple. Light-bodied, with medium carbonation and a crisp mouthfeel. Meh.

Can shared at b3shines. Pours a darker gold with a thick white head of foam that dissipates quickly. Smells like skunk piss and white cake. Tastes better than it smells and is pretty sweet. This is alright, but Ill pass in the future.

My bottle is labeled differently. There is a bigger lion head at the top and the label reads Lion Imperial Premium Malt Pilsner. The alcohol content is listed at 8.8%, not 8.0. This is a decent pilsner. It has a thin mouth with a smooth sweet malty flavor that is easy to swallow. The alcohol is undetectable. I am going to enjoy another one right now. Try one.
Sweet smell like caramel faintly. Alcohol feeling conspicuous. There is no lingering and pleasant fragrance. I seem to just soda water.

Easy to drink. Golden pour with slight haze and white head. Aroma is primarily malt. Taste is creamy sweet malt. Has a slight citrus or astringent finish. Dont really notice the high alcohol content. Good buzz delivery method.

330 ml can. 8.8%. 115410559. BB Nov 2012. From Malaysia. Thanks Mark!
Cloudy golden colour with a tiny white head.
The aroma is malt, buttery sweetness and mild citrus. The flavour is malty. And sweet. And its surprisingly smooth. Dont wanna drink much more but its not as bad as I expected. Rather drinkable malt liquor.
Aroma is perfumed and slightly astringent malts.  The flavor is grain sweetness, mild earthiness and a slightly tart/alcoholic finish.
Bottle. Slightly hazy gold pour with a small white head. Lots of sweet corn in this, and a bit medicinal and boozy. Not a fan.

Pours a slightly hazy orange yellow. Foamy white head. Aroma is malt and citrus. Taste is overly sweet without much of a bitter offset. Too sweet to try again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle. golden with small head. boozy with corn. sweet and medicinal. very overdone.

11.2oz bottle - pours misty yellow with quickly diminishing white head and modest lacing. Nose is boiling pasta with corn. Flavor adds floral hops and malt liquor. Alcohol burn. Light to moderate sweetness. Almost certain this beer gets the job done for real cheap. Chicken feed aftertaste (cracked dry corn). That is all.

This beer really cannot compare to its darker cousin, the Lion Stout.  Whereas the latter is world class, this one blends into mediocrity. Surprisingly alcoholic, and more of that alcohol flavor shouldve been disguised.  Bready malts, some caramel, with a medium body.

11.2oz Bottle. The pour was a clear golden yellow with an average (1-2 finger) white fizzy head that was mostly diminishing with poor spotty lacing.

The aroma was lightly sweet with a light grain malt, floral and grassy hops and a sweaty yeast and had notes of caramel, honey, a slight fruity ester (apple I believe) and a mild medicinal scent.

The taste was lightly sweet and very malty with light hints of caramel and honey from the start, and then had a mild taste of hops slowly work in to the mix with the finish having a mild fruity alcohol presence towards the end. The flavor hung on for an average time proceeding the swallow, with a slight alcohol sweetness and a more pronounced hoppy grain flavor that was left to linger on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was a bit beyond light in body with a light syrupy texture and a medium carbonation.

Overall this was a somewhat sweet fruity brew that had a good hop and grain taste along with a bold alcohol presence. Basically this was a tasty Pilsner with a kick...
Very cidery. It wasnt horrible but was close. Very strong so it has that going for it if you want strong beer. Thin, no body, hard cider notes. No thanks.
lion, grrrrrrrrrr.   smells like a lion from behind.  it bursts with crispy malt and flowery hops
Tastes like a cheap lager, which is basically what it is. Its got a lot of the skunkiness that export lagers have. Meh.

So much alcohol, such an odd taste.  Clear gold with a nice rim head and a thick stripe of lace.  The taste begins with malt which gives way to a lightly spiced caramel that continues through the finish.  It is heavy, it is filling, it isnt appealing, so it doesnt work for me.  Not recommended.

Okay aroma, little too floral. Great look, transparent gold body, white head that leaves a good lace. Tastes awful, cloyingly sweet and tastes like perfume. Actually starts fine, but just piles on in the back and leaves a strong aftertaste. Feels okay, but a little thin. AVOID.
Bottle from Total Wine, Sacramento. Pours light amber with an attractive white head and a nondescript aroma. There is a slightly fruity pale malt flavor with a dry finish.

Strong, malty aroma has a sweet, fruity overtone and a hint of honey. It pours a lovely clear amber with a fairly thick white head. Sweet, malty flavor is almost like a cider, but has a good alcohol bite and just a hint of hops. Smooth texture has firm body but lacks fizz. Overall, a nice robust pilsner.
Pours pale, cloudy yellow. Nose has the first impression of alcohol, followed by some bread, and raisin.  Really funky flavors, kind of like drinking an alcohol flavored dirty sock...

An average lager at best, but note the higher alcohol content. Reminiscent of a Bass Ale, but has a very watery mouthfeel and no aftertaste, Might be better suited for the Indian Ocean climate where it was brewed for, and   enjoyed as a decent summer quencher.
(bottle) clear yellowish amber colour with small white head; aroma of stewed fruit; balanced flavour, decent

This beer is kind of a sleeper hit in my opinion. I see the low ratings, but I think this is a beer worth trying. The color is pretty typical, golden-yellow straw with a head that dissipates quickly. The beer tastes very light, but the alcohol content says otherwise. It definitely has fruit notes, lemon and slight banana. The finish is sweet, but not overpowering. Would I buy this again? Yes. Is it worth trying? Absolutely. Are all the low ratings really a reflection of how this beer really tastes? I dont think so.
Nice golden color; Medium body; Aroma of malt, some yeast, & grain; Flavor of sweet malt, grain, honey, and some light fruit; Overall, not too good - had a chemical taste to it.
12 oz bottle from Total Wine and More Sacramento.  This is the only beer Ive dumped out all year.  It was gross with very little redeeming quality.

bottle.  8.8%.  lightly hazed gold with a fine white head.  sweet corn mush and plastic bag nose with stinky apple and pear esters.  medium-full body but carbonation is frothy and light.  too sweet, too estery.

I like to keep things simple:  Is it good, Yes.  Would I buy it again, Yes.  Is it something I would go out of my way to get, No.  
Overall rating:  A solid "try it"

Bottle (8.8% ABV).

Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is clear dark yellow.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, husks), lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs), with light notes of baked apple, detergent, and DMS.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Wouldnt be surprised if Imperial Lager/Pilsner and Strong Beer are really the same, just with varying ABVs and names depending on marketing strategy.  Anyways, its not terribly clean in the nose but what is surprising is how well hidden the alcohol is and how nicely balanced and textured it is in the mouth (for a beer of this type).  If only the acetaldehyde and DMS and huskiness werent in the aroma, this could be quite nice.  Still, much better than expected considering the swill quality of the regular lager.

Orlando, Fl - Whole Foods - 300 ml bottle. Pours a slightly murky dark golden with a thin white head. Aroma is a bit muddled with some booziness and yeast. Flavor has a heavy yeast presence, some orange marmalade-like sweetness, some sweet cake mix maltiness. Mouthfeel is thick enough.  Not bad for the sub-continent

(330ml bottle) light gold pour with fine white ring of bubbles. Nose of alcohol, grain, kind of stinky, and sweet smelling. Taste is very sweet, alcoholic, sugary, grainy, apple juice, and un-carbonated.

12 oz can bought in Denver and opened into pint glass in San Diego.  Looks pretty clear and corn yellow.  White head.  Smells of sweet sour and alch.  Tastes pretty thick Lager.  Some sour grape tastes.  Overall 5 of 10.

(can 6/12/10). Clear gold color. Small white head. Light fruity citrus aroma, with light sweet malt. Flavor of the same, with moderate alcohol. Avg duration. Dry finish with moderate alcohol. Thin texture. Soft to moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

12oz can, $1.67 at Dutchs. ABV listed as 8.8%. Clear wheaty yellow color, frothy white head. Not much aroma, mild lagery yeast, mild alcohol. Not painful, just uninteresting. Smooth and not over-carbonated, that is nice.
rich in flavor, many taste of grass, wheat, honey malt, earthy and lots of herbs, with a strong flavor but mellows out on the hops taste.  quite smooth on the palate. works all the way around.
Bottle.  Pours a clear gold with a nice white head.  Aroma of malt and grain.  Taste is sweet malt, yeast and grass.  OK at best.

Kind of your generic imperial lager, sweet and a light hop presence that good definitely double as a higher quality malt liquor.  Not delicious, but I was able to finish my half the bottle easily enough.
Bottled, thanks to thirdeye11, clear yellow pour with a sweet sauvignon blanc aroma, flavor is honey and citrus fruits, malts

(330ml bottle, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a clear golden body with a small white head.  Aroma of chemicals, soap, florals, and grass.  Flavor of soap, caramel, subtle apple cider vinegar, earth, grass, and light chemicals.

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a yellow color with a white head. The aroma is a mix of bread and lemons. The flavor is grain and bready malt. Fairy bland and not near as hoppy as I was expecting from an Imperial Pilsner. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Not a bad beer, just nothing that really stands out.

Lion Imperial Pilsner is a dense, crystal clear golden lager with a white head that fades to a film and leaves good lacing.  It has a very faint aroma of cardboard and grass.  Its medium bodied and very lively.  The finish is sharp and it leaves the mouth chalky.  Its quite sweet and not bitter enough to balance things out.  Its tangy with a little noble hop character.  There are no off flavors but its not refined.  Its very drinkable for 8.8% ABV.  Theres no alcohol flavor.  It could serve as a session beer, but things could get out of hand if it did.

12 oz can with a black label and the word "imperial" extra large and the word "lager" is not there.  Perhaps to make one think it is an imperial stout?  Tasting with a cold so senses are blunted.  Flavor is sugary, syrupy, a dash of honey, equal amount of grain, and a dollop of fruit.  Alcohol comes out at the finish.  This beer screams low quality.  Its not quite a malt liquor but its not far from it.
Pours golden with thick white head and some lacing.  Traditional pils notes of hay and grass.  Balanced taste of hops and grains.

Hmm...smells good, like honey, and of course the 8% is a plus, but it tastes like overly sweet alcohol. And now, coming back to smell it again, I can definitely smell the unpleasantly sweet alcohol. Pours golden amber-- like a LION--ugg, this sugary aftertaste just destroys it for me though.

Grabbed this one in a hurry and was expecting to have an imperial stout that night, only to pour a pilsner. The aroma was of alcohol with almost a cheap white wine/grape note. Malty alcohol flavor that was very dry and fizzy - felt kind of like i was drinking cheap champagne.

Underwhelming attempt at a Pilsener, this beer has a flavor profile closer to a malt liquor. Aroma shows heavy corn adjunct with a bit of honey. Hops are nowhere to be found. Body is heavy and slick with ample alcohol warming, and lasting corny aftertaste. Ill pass.
10/2/10.  Bottle.  Sweet and sour aroma and flavor that reminds me of a homebrewed infected cider.

330ml bottle, consumed while still fairly cold.  Malty, musty aroma, very lightly sweet and vegetal with notes of cereal grains.  Clear light-medium golden color with an amber cast and a fine, uneven head.  Flavor is oddly sweet and sugary with a weak backbone of hop bitterness and herbal flavor.  Palate is not nearly clean enough for the style, leaving all kinds of chemical-like sweetness around for some time, body is actually pretty full.  As some have pointed out, not nearly in the same low class as your standard domestic malt liquor, but certainly not something I need to try a second time.

can - Pours clear yellow and very fizzy with a minimal head consisting of big, rapidly disappearing bubbles.  The aroma is grainy malt and a little alcohol with a touch of fruit.  The flavor is of sweet malt with corn and other grains and just a bit of fruitiness.  The corn is not as strong as it would be in a malt liquor and this beer is smoother, but thats about all I can say on its behalf.  Its bland, almost syrupy, and has no noticeable hops bitterness.

Pours a golden tan with a thin head.  Nose has sweet candies and fruity malts.  Taste is also on the sweet side, lacks depth.  A bit cloying and hard to drink more than a few ounces.  Body is too thick and undercarbonated.
Thanks to Joe Mcphee. Strong malt, honey aroma. Slightly spiced. Clear yellow colour with a thin white lace. Nice texture. Slightly smooth and syrup like. Malt citrus and honey flavour.

12-oz bottle.

Aroma - Strange. Apple vinegar. Yeast. Spices. Alcohol.

Appearance - Looks promising. Clear and golden with billowy white head.

Taste - Huge malty sweetness, almost syrupy, medicinal, some caramel notes. Pretty boozy. The seeming lack of hop bitterness to offset the intense sweetness is a bit problematic. Strange side notes: metal, balsamic vinegar, cough syrup.

Palate - Medium bodied.

Overall - The most bizarre beer I have ever tasted. I am not quite sure what the brewers were trying to accomplish.

Pour form a 12 oz bottle. Medium to dark yellow with a huge white head. Sweet, slightly corney aroma, but nothing unpleasant. Flavor is sweet corn syrup followed with a sweet vodka like alcohol aftertaste. virtually no hops in the flavor. Makes me appreciate Duvel.

Sure, "smooth taste" might be a stretch. "Refreshment" might not be apt. But any beer thats brewed specifically to achieve "high alcohol content" is OK in my book.  Dont complain: Lion knows what its giving you, and you know what youre getting.

330 ml bottle, $1.80 @ Binnys. At least this one doesnt call itself "Imperial" because its from a former colony! Poured in a shaker. Dark golden pils color, even a hint of red, under a big foamy head. Yet, the smell is kind of skunky. Okay, at least it doesnt not an over-sugared malt liquor. But the taste: yikes! Sugary and a bit bilious. With some air in the glass, theres some tartness that could be likened to a tripel, but its one golden thread in a pile of used dental floss. None of the other rating on the front page indicate any problems, and a beer this strong shouldnt be this skunked. I guess if you dont sniff too much, you can get a heady nose of alcohol. But this just does not go down well for me.

Sampled in a 330 ml bottle. Pours golden brown. Clear crisp with a thin white head on it. A really good drink. Malting is a bit rough which has to do a lot with the high alcohol content. Much better than I expected.

Can. Pours a strong, dark gold with a substantial, pure white head. Nose of overripe fruit, corn, alcohol, and intensely sweet malts. Flavor is a bit over the top: Huge malty sweetness, almost syrupy, medicinal, some caramel ntoes. Pretty boozy. The seeming lack of hop bitterness to offset the intense sweetness is a bit problematic. Medium to full bodied.  Finish is more syrupy sweetness, which lingers for too long. If you like malt liquors, you would probably like this. Apparently I dont like malt liquor enough, because it was tough for me to get through this beer.

Pours a deep golden color, lot of carbonation and a tall, bubbly, white head. Aroma has a strong grainy nose, lots of grassy hops, strong alcohol note, almost a cream ale sweetness and mild malty sweetness as a whole. Flavor has a very strong grassy presence first thing with lots of grains late in the tasting and a hot alcohol nip at the end. Body is pretty heavy with a fizzy feeling. Overall not my type of beer by any stretch of the imagination. Grassy and grainy combo are bit too much. The body is pretty nice and the alcohol is there but slightly softened by the big body, just not enough.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a golden color with a light white head.  Aromas of caramel and butterscotch.  A lot stronger than I expected until I looked at the bottle and noticed that it said 8.8%.  Has some bitterness.  Medium bodied.  A slight alcohol burn at the end.
Brilliant golden color/ lasting white foam. Burnt rubber, smoke stack  industrial aromas with some sweet berry maltiness. Light frothy mouthfeel. Yeasty fruity flavors of pils malts, light berry.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Appearance: Pours out a faintly hazed, dark yellow body with a short-lived, white head.

Smell: Basal, simple nose smelling of grainy pils malt, transient fruit notes, a small addition of Noble hops, and fermented honey.

Taste: Lightly grainy cereal-minded maltiness coated with no more than a bit of honey sweetness. Floral, mildly spicy hop tones with a modest amount of balancing bitterness. scant hint of fruitiness akin to apple and maybe a few drops of choice melon juice. Small sip of white wine in advance of the drying finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Theres a smooth slickness to the mouthfeel, but the alcohol seems to cut the body down.

Drinkability: Eh. I see and have heard a few comparisons to malt liquor, and while its not quite that bad, its not that much better, either.

Name: Lion Imperial Pilsner
Date: January 03, 2010
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Ticker
Appearance: hazy gold, wispy white head
Aroma: light floral hop aroma, hint of sweet malt
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, touch of candy sweetness, light balancing bitterness
Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 9/20
Rating: 2.4/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: ** /4

330 ml bottle purchased at MDL in Overland Park, Kansas.  Served in a tulip.  Pour is a hazed yellow gold with a 1/2 inch white head that falls quick. Aroma is sweet maltiness, followed by some straw and a touch of spice-clove yeast. Taste is the sweet malt of the nose, less natural than the nose, a bit chemical, followed by clove, and finishing with a dryness and a slight bit of booze. Aftertaste is honey sweetness. Palate is medium, oily, with fizzy carbonation.

It pours a sparkling clear, pale gold color with a white, creamy, fluffy, average head which is somewhat lasting and leaves some drippy lace.  The nose is a bit offputting with apples, spicy hops, metal, and sweet grains.  The flavors carries less metallic notes which helps, but overall fairly boring with a weird apple pie notes (cooked apples, cinnamon, sweet grains) and just hints at spicy hops.  The palate is fair with a light to medium body, lively carbonation, and a creamy but watery mouthfeel.  The finish is average with sweet apples, spicy cinnamon, even a bit sugary.  Not quite a drain pour but not what I look for in an imp. pils.  Not a brewery I am too fond of.

Bottle: Deep golden with clarity and a white film of head. The aroma is all sulfur- lit match and burnt rubber, what the... Has a slick sweet body. Corn syrup cheap macro maltose with again, a strong sulfuric presence of burning rubber and off phenolics. Sugary and very off.

Bottle pours deep gold with a large creamy white head.  Aroma is heavy in sweet grain, honey, pear, apple, grass, and a slight herbal note that I cannot put my finger on.  Flavor shows the same with a tiny amount of white pepper to back it up.  Pleasant at first, but an extremely deceiving beer, because as it warms it starts to fall apart.  The alcohol starts to poke holes in the dense blanket of sugar that seems to have been hiding it, leaving behind a very confused beer.   Overall body is moderate and the carbonation is soft.  Probably deserves a lower score, but did have some merit.

Bottle.  Pours hazy golden yellow with a small white head.  Aroma is of honey, grass, floral hops.  Flavor is malty, sweet honey, grassy, apple.  Little in the way of hops.  Thick, creamy palette.  Alcohol is well masked.  A bit odd -- Ive never tasted anything quite like it.  Not bad, but probably wont be rushing out to have it again.  I dont think I get the point of a high alcohol pilsner that doesnt have a crisp, hoppy edge.

Nice golden color with a tall lingering head. Smells of sweet grass and herbs. Full nectar with good carbonation. A sweet malty brew that really goes well with my shrimp cocktail (high in heat). Very little hop essence. Cloyingly sweet. Lingering finish.

Bottled, thanks to Bill!  Poured slightly hazy straw golden with a tall cap of white head.. looked quite good.  The aroma was sweet with honey and slight vegetal notes paired with black peppery alcohol.. started out alright, but the longer it sat, the more offensive it got.  The flavor found honey, corn, and some pale malts at the core, with bright, corn-based alcohol resonating outward.. some floral bitterness surrounded.. finished with lots of sugars that masked the boozage decently.  Medium-bodied and warm on the palate with lots of sugars all over the place.. this actually wasnt that bad, but definitely not worth a re-visit.

Beer poor scopper with almost no head but a nice stream of bubbles.  Aroma is nice but very subdued.  Beer has an excellent clean tast with a bit of very slight bitterness balanced well with malt.  Palate is great and in fact I was suprised to see the ABV upon rating the beer.  Does not taste like an 8% beer.  Overall the beer was very nice.  Id like to grab some for summer time, just watch out for how many you have.
Aroma that is very sweet cherry, flavor is strong notes of alcohol and sweet surgary fruits. Deliscious and very strong. Bottle at Zekes Roadhouse, Miami Beach.

330mL bottle.  8.8%ABV!  Deep golden pour.  Aroma of golden raisin and a touch of Riesling.    Smooth, creamy, somewhat heavy bodied.  A touch of cider sweetness.  Very nice, a bit strong, but very nice and smooth.
Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow color with a white head.  Aroma is honey, rich apple, some toast, and slightly floral.  Flavor is honey, apple, grain, fruity, and a light floral finish.
Bottle. Pours clear gold with a thin head. Sweet aroma, almost like a malt liqour but slightly better. The flavor has a graint malty sweetness and low bitterness. Blah.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2009 (br-btl bk/gl-lbl, Imperial Lager, 8%)

lct-stw, no head, med-light-body, med-high-co2.

aroma: ^strange, concord-grape, sweet-pepper-jelly.

flavor: §pale-malt, ^corn-liquer, ^fusel-alchl(biodiesel / gasoline).

very strange green-pepper or tomato-vine aftertaste, is there any such thing as cheap noble hop flavor additive concentrate? i think they spilled a bit extra into the beer.

12oz bottle, no date.  Clear golden with a creamy 1 1/2 finger offwhite head, fair retention.  Corn, stale crackers, and some old grain dominate the aroma.  The flavor adds alcohol and some dirt, bitterness peaked at a 2 in the finish.  Thick body with low carb. For the style.  I found zero redeeming qualities in this.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours gold with a big white head.  Aroma is light bready malts and a little bit of earthy hop.  Flavor is light bready malts with a little bit of alchohol and syrup like quality.  Not bad.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2011 Poured from bottle into Tulip.  Slightly hazy, pale orange-yellow with very active (and loud) bubbles and head, but the head subsides very quickly with no lacing. Looked pretty good for about a minute and a half.  Aroma of German noble hops, semi-sweet malt, cheap alcohol. Unfortunately, the hop smell disappeared, leaving mostly the cheap alcohol.  Wow, that does not taste the same as the somewhat dry, hoppy smell. Very, very sweet, like candy, but very peppery hops counter and are prominent at the finish. Tastes like a Malt Liquor with out of place hops. Cloying.  Pretty carbonated, light to medium body, feels alcoholic (if that makes sense).  Adding this note from a short while after I finished: I have an awful aftertaste in my mouth still.
Sweet alcohol, grains, pasteurized aroma. Harsh, alcoholic malty taste, some barnyard and straw as well. Not a fan of this one. LOVE the stout however.
sample.  atlanta hotoberfest.  gold under a huge white head.  malty strong aroma.  honey and sweet with noticeable alcohol.  peppery, sweaty flavors.  not good.

Pour is a hazy golden with a large white head.  Aroma is an ok pils malt with some yeastyness in there. Flavor is heavy sweet malt with an almost honey like presence.  Very sweet and heavy.  Kinda malt liquorish but the alcohol is hidden well.  Still, I wont be needing this again.

Pours out a clear golden amber with a fizzy white head that shrinks rather quickly. Aroma is mostly sweet pils malt with a grassy hop note. The flavor starts off with a ton of sweet malt, some hops come out, but the malt is still very much the star of this show. Some light alcohol warming on the end, to go along with the ever-present sweet malt. Slow sweet finish. More than full bodied, with a light tickle of carbonation. Pretty good lager.

Single 330mL bottle from Total Wine in Huntersville, NC.  This is one heavy bottle - the quality of the bottle is obviously the key to keep this lager fresh on a trip from Sri Lanka to the US.  Pours a clear gold color with a white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a touch of hops. Flavor is malt at the beginning with a small alcohol presence, small hops bite and a warming effect.  This hides the alcohol well and I was impressed with this rather strong tasting beer.

Brewed in Sri Lanka, the Lion Imperial Lager boasts a proud lion on its bottle cap and bottle label, his golden eyes gleaming at me as his equally bright gold contents fill my lager glass. Im not quite sure how natural a golden yellow that is, though a tall and proud head of fluffy white foam makes for the perfect mane. Raising my glass, I am immediately overtaken by sweet golden corn, fresh off the cob, cooked and sweetened. A bare whisper of dry straw and hay flits through the background, but quickly yields to the glass of corn sitting before me. Let me say right now that an overly corny beer is never a good thing. My first quaff is thick as his flavor aims right for the top of my tongue where I find a new crop of sweet summer corn growing most magnificently. Too thick and too sweet, he cloys and clogs, making for a hard swallow. Sweet corn which I enjoy fresh off the cob to eat is one thing; this is another issue entirely. Cooked and artificially sweetened, a growing backdrop of dank, soggy hay grows with each subsequent quaff. I have had about all I can stomach, and it is with somber clarity that I share the rest of my glass contents with the kitchen sink.


Horrible. I tried it, but I just didnt like it, and Im not the only one I fear. Sure, he has a higher alcohol because of the imperializing but a beers ABV is second to none when it comes to what matters first: taste. Hopefully I will never come across another Lion Imperial Lager, but if I do, I am going to calmly and slowly take a step back, turn around without making eye contact, and head in the opposite direction to safety, and to good beer.

Sri Lankan malt liquor?  This strong pilsener is very malty with little or no hop flavor.  Killer strength and warming, but nothing to brag about.  Pours classic golden with a nice head that quickly settles.

This is a large beer.  Golden, with a modest head.  Malt aroma, with little hint of the jolt to come.  Heavy, thick and strong.  The malt and alcohol come through.  Finishes with a heavy malt sweetness.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot, Willowbrook, Illinois:  It poured a clear golden body with a respectable head that didnt want to hang around for too long.  The aroma was sweet fresh grain with a dollop of honey and a dash of diesel fuel... the last not strong enough to be too detrimental.  The flavor was much the same with little to cut the sweetness besides the alcohol.  Oddly, tho, it was fairly drinkable... and warming.

12oz bottle.  Orange-tan color with a thin head.  Potent sweet sugary aroma.  There is some honey sweetness, but there is also some Eastern European ruggedness.  I thought the other Lion products were complex and sublime, but this one kind of just goes for the alcohol overkill.  Too strong and too sweet for its own good, would have benefited from some hop balance.  Drinkable, but unimpressive.
Bottle. Pours a amber body. The aroma is malt. The taste is honey and too much alcohol... sort of tasted like malt liquor
UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 As a novice Lager drinker I was excited to try this. A bit too sweet however for my palate, not bad just not my thing.

Bottle from Stephs sister in internatiional multipack.  Clear golden color with small to medium creamy white head.  Aroma is light grain and lager yeast with dry spicey hops and subtle lightly sweet malt.  Flavor defintely knocked me back a little with heavy malt with medium sweetness, a little biscuit, a noticable alc presence, caramel, lager yeast and light hops.  Medium and slightly syrupy body, light carbonation.  Interesting, the syrupy body and sweetness doesnt work for me as well as the almost acetone like light alc presence.  What does work for me is that its not completely unbalanced for what it is.  I also like the slight grapiness.
Hot, semi-syrupy sweet, and unbalanced. The worst of this style that Ive had to date
Despite the "imperial" label, I did not get too much beyond the lager taste. Pretty basic and if I were a lager drinking, I might be impressed.

Pours clear deep gold with 10 second white head. The aroma is sugar sweet malts mixing with apricots, pears, apples, a sense of dark grapes and faint chemical booze. The taste starts a tad sharp with the carbonation pushing notes of plums, apricots, apples and pears across the palate. Midway sugar sweet malts surface. The light colored fruitiness wanes into the finish as the mouthfeel dries out some. Decent enough stuff since it ended less sweet than it started.

12 oz. bottle.   Pours a clear gold with a very tall, pillowy, white head.  Very faint nose that reminded me a bit of play-doh.  Light grain notes as well.  Low carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Light sweet grain, cereal, and fusel alcohol on the palate.  Short finish.  Pretty nondescript.

Bottle Clear yellow lager with a small, creamy, white head. The aroma is a bit lactic and vinous  smells a touch like white wine. Medium to full-bodied with lively carbonation. Leans on the sweet side of balance. Obligatory, mild bitterness. Sweet, minerally finish.

Golden with a rocky white head.  Aroma of grains, sweet malts, light caramel.  Soft and syrupy body.  Strong malts, alcohol, sugary sweet, and Belgian style yeast notes.  Dry finish.  Interesting brew, would drink again.

Like a classy malt liqour. Vey full bodied. Alcohol on the nose and in the mouthful. I would drink again if I was offered at the price. Could use a bit more hops to straighten out the big malts.decent. A point or two for the price
Poured golden orange, sweet apple, bready, little corn, little honey, slight grassy hops.

Bottle from total wine.  Pours a golden color with an average white head. Aroma is sweet, grainy and some apple juice.  Flavor is also sweet, corn, cereal and finishes pretty quickly on the tonue.  Not really a high grade beer.
Bottle: Poured a golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet grass. Taste is metallic, fruit, and grain.
Sweet cereal grains on the nose with honey.  Pours light blonde with a thin white head.  Fruity and sweet, apple cider and apple skins, not very good at all.

Sampled on 3/6/2009. This Strong Lager pours a deep orange gold color from a 33cl bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet, some grain and spice. A medium bodied Strong Lager. The malts are fruity and sweet, lots of orange flavors. Grainy and cereal, it has that high gravity mouthfeel to it. The hops are earthy. A little alcohol hot, well a lot alcohol hot. Kind of artificial and medicinal lasting as well, but then it is a European Strong Lager. A malt liquor, but a better than average ML.  Mouthfeel is full. Finish is crisp and harsh. Aftertaste is alcohol and sharp.

Wow ok. Dark golden with foamy white head that subsides fast. Aroma of dust, plastic, and creamed corn. Mouthfeel is sticky, but not hugely so. Flavors are mainly sweet and oily, but thankfully vanish fast after the phenolic finish.

Deep gold with a chill haze.  Well, it smells like a champ.  The aroma is full of sweet grains and some sour canned fruit stuff.  Malt-accented palate with reasonable alcohol.  Tastes a bit cidery, but also really sweet, and with some paint-like phenols.  Its going to lose points for a distinctly gluey finish.  Not much good in this, time for me to move on.

330 ml bottle which I received as a Christmas gift from my friend Russell.  Pours a hazy antique gold with a thin white head that disappeared before my eyes.  Strong aroma of skunk, black pepper, sweet malt and sugar.  I opened a second bottle to make sure the skunkiness wasnt specific to the bottle I was sampling, and got a good whiff in that one too.  Thankfully, the skunk is not an issue in the flavor, which is sweet malt, overripe apples, sugar and alcohol.  Definite warming from the alcohol at the finish along with moderate bitterness.  If you need a rating from Sri Lanka, try to locate the stout.  This one is really not very good.

Clear golden coloured body with a super-thin white head. Aroma of caster sugar, wheat, corn, alcohol and a bunch of funky clean fruits.Medium to Light-bodied; Strong assertive malts up front fading to a pleasant sweetness and an odd maltiness. Aftertaste shows more fruit and malt than anything else, although no harsh bitterness. Overall, for a beer at 8%, I was expecting much more bitterness, but this was fairly muted. Granted, the stout is MUCH better than this one, but this isnt a horrible beer. Overall, good to try; I wouldnt purchase this again, but Im glad I tried this. That said, if you need to choose between this and the stout, DEFINITELY choose the stout! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Ramsey Liquors in Ramsey, New Jersey on 19-January-2009, sampled at home in Washington on 29-January-2009.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2009 The aroma is alcoholic with flowers and sweet malt. The appearance is golden with a large head. The taste is like the aroma.  It is also like fuel from the alcohol. This beer does not try to hid the alcohol in any way. The palate is smooth. Overall bad stuff. This is like a malt liquor only better than OE or Colt 45 because it lacks corn taste and has some flowery hops.

Aroma of grass and hay with a hint of vanilla, mild and neutral. Golden-yellow color with a 1/2" white head and lots of splotchy lacing. Sweet on the palate with a nice bite after the swallow, mildly bitter. Premium malt liquor taste (in a good way). Sweet and dry malts that are pale and grainy. There is a sprinkling of grassy hops to help provide some balance to this monster lager. Smooth, drinkable high octane lager.

Tasted 11/9/08.  330ml bottle.  Filtered with a golden hue.  Actization brings about a finger with of billowing bone white head.  Aromas of cereal grains and subtle esters.  Touch lemon candy.  Decent aromas.  Medium bodied with a surprisingly pleasant first sip.  Sweet and smooth with an odd Frankenberry Marshmellow flavor.  Sugary malts and moderate effervescence.  Rather tangy, bitter finish.

[bottle - 330 ml] Clear golden color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a touch of grains and hops. Flavor is rather malty at the beginning with a very small alcohol presence, an even smaller hop bite, and a light warming effect. Finishes sweet. Does not taste like 8.8% at all.

Bottle from Total WIne in Roseville. Darker gold color with a 3-finger white head. Aromas of grain and spicey hop. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Its certainly different. It shows heat. It is grainy. It suggests a malt liquor in effect, but a top end version. Interesting.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a straw color with a thin white head.  Some cloudiness, but looks more like a dirty cloudy, than a tasty cloudy.  Aroma is light and grainy.  Flavor is sweet grain and malt, with hints of raisin and dried fruit.  Not much alcohol flavor for an 8% brew.  Palate is medium bodied, kind of dead.  Overall a drinkable beer, but not one of my favorites.

Bottle from College Liquors in Grand Junction, CO. Pours a crystal clear golden color with a small white bubbly head. The aroma is mostly skunky corn and grains. The flavor is pretty much full of sweet corn and other adjuncts, a sour mash, and skunked flavor. I’m not sure how fresh this was, but it was just a OK lager.

12oz bottle-pours a frothy to rocky and retaining white head and yellow/gold color.  Aroma is sweet grain-caramel, grassy, some spicy hops.  Taste is sweet grain-caramel, grassy, secondary spicy/herbal/earthy hops bitterness.  Thanks jwc215 for sharing.
Poured a clear yellow/orange with a large white head.  Aroma of apple juice and rice.  Taste is pretty sweet with some hops.  The finish isn’t too great, and you can tell there is more alcohol.

12oz bottle marked as 8.8% ABV: Clear gold pour with a smallish head that dissipates.  The aroma is malt forward with heavy notes of fresh dough, wet hay, wildflower honey.  The body follows the same flow, lots of sweet malts.  The ethery alcohol whispers in the background, hinting at this being a heavy hitter.  Interesting style that is done well here.

This is a tasty, nicely balanced strong lager that is very smooth and easy to drink while maintaining good flavour and body throughout.  Dark gold, it has a big, off-white head that slowly shrinks and leaves a little lace. The aroma has bread, grapes, raisins, fruit , vanilla and riesling. It’s sweet and fruity (esp. grapes), with fresh sweet bread/bakery character and with a spicey, zesty quality. A pleasant, mild hop character balances the malt.
Pours gold with a thin white head.  Smells of corn, some straw, alcohol.  Tastes of dry malt and some hoppy hints with a boozy finish.
Clear golden color with a big white head. Aroma of corn and some sweet malts. Sweet grainy flavor with some alcohol.

The very mild, sweet, grainy lager aroma is extremely overpowered by the offensive smell of cheap, corn sugar alcohol. Pours a pale yellow/gold with no head to speak of. Tastes almost exactly like Steel Reserve, a very cheap and foul malt liquor styled lager. Heavy alcohol flavor and bite that masks an overly sweet, underhopped, undermalted beverage of little distinction. Overall, I was extremely disappointed that this came from the same brewery that makes the sublime, almost faultless Lion Stout. You are warned.
Not much aroma. Well, this doesznt hide the alcohol at all!! Strong from the star, it gets a little bit better in the end.  Seems a bit like a malt liqour.

Bottle.  Thought that the very idea of an "imperial lager" sounded interesting, but pour looks pretty blah... light and clear gold color with a slight head that is fizzy and ephimeral.  Aromas are apple juice and spice.  Flavor is very sweet... almost like a sparkling apple juice or something with a little bit of a spicy side to it and a corn/adjunct flavor.  Really not as exciting as I had hoped.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Not much head, golden color and the aroma of fruits.  Tasted like Grapefruit and flowers.  Good beer.

bottle.  clear yellow body with tiny white (fully dissapating) head.  aromas of almost a christmas spice, corn, licorice.  long finish duration.  sweet flavor.  alcohol is well hidden, though this one is not for me.
Golden color. Lots of sugar to boost the abv. Alcohol taste is pretty low. Thin to no head. Way to sweet for me.

i thought this thing was pretty disgusting.  Pours out a pale yellow color with nearly no head.  aroma was that of corn and grain.  flavor was the same but full of alcohol.  Did not care for this one at all.
Strong and sweet but somewhat greasy, it was plain and not very impresive, but at least it helped me to sleep in my depression. Was nice to have it wihtout troubles.
Pours yellow, smells bit of hops. Flavor is full for a lager with a sharp abrupt bite at the end. Overall, nice for a lager, not worth the 10 bucks for a 6 pack however.
Pours yellow with some minor lacing. Thin, fine, white head. Aroma is pleasantly, light and grassy. Moderate thought feel with a sweet, grassy, fruity flavor and a good, complimentary hop bitterness.
Sri Lanka!!! extrange aroma, like a peanuts and fruit. In mouth remember me like a belgium beer taste. 8 ºAlcohol good color and better flavor the bitternes is good with the malt flavor.

Poured into a pint glass. Pours a frankly pee-colored yellow with an inch of white head. The suds reduces to a blotchy cap leaving some unexpectedly substantial lacing.

Nose is citrusy with a faint metallicness. Also some grainy sweetness.

Flavor is grainy caramel maltiness with a buttery note at the end. Some tart citrus and an almost candy-like sweetness round things out. 

Mouthfeel is pleasantly dry for the amount of sweetness, but its also overcarbonated. The medium-light mouthfeel cant really contend with the alcohol level either.

Drinkability is hampered by the high alcohol and the eventually cloying sweetness.
Sweet aroma of malt and grain with some candy notes.  Taste is similar but even sweeter with some bitter herbs and definately some alcohol showing through.

Pours bright golden with a fully receding off-white head. Aroma of sweet grain, some ethanol and fusels, cookie dough, candied malt, herbal hop bitterness. Taste is sticky, malty, sweet candied malt with some herbal bitterness. Mouthfeel is full bodied with moderate carbonation. I’m generally not a big fan of golden lagers brewed to a high ABV,but this wasn’t bad. More drinkable than the typical Euro Strong Lager.

Bottle shared by EDA. A strong, skunky lager, massively corny and sickly sweet. Typical and expected in every regard, I cant imagine much worse than a shitty lager thats been amped up to 8%. This really tastes like that bottle of yuengling I had that froze in my garage and I dranked "eis"ed.
gold color with a small head. Flavor is a bit boozy with just a slight corn flavor. Second taste is getting pretty disguisting. Third taste is like novocaine.  Uncle!

Ugh...this is awful! The one thing I will admit..this does NOT taste like an 8%er. Aroma was weak. Could pick up light malt but barely. Pour was a light gold with no head or bubbles. Taste was very sweet and thick. Could pick up malt but very heavy in the sugar. This tastes like malt liquor to me. Wow...as I get to the middle this may be a drainpour.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The color was light golden/orange.  The head was creamy, thin, and off-white.  The aroma was tart, acidic, and lacking.  The flavor was light alcohol, corn, and bran.  The palate was thin/medium bodied.  The finish was a little warm.

Pours a golden yellow with a thin frothy offwhite head. The aroma is weird, smells like glue, bad glue. Man that smells weird. Ok then it melts into grassy hops, hay. Warm wet hay. Oh god, this thing tastes weird. Warm alcohol, wet hay. Yikes. Okay, feels hot and dry and weird. Hoo...ray.
Was Not the dark Lager I was hoping for. The color was nice and after that it was a letdown. BLA BLA .very malty  and 8%
Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark golden color with almost no head. The aroma was typical sour, tangy lager. The flavor was tangy, sour, bitter and almost skunky. Drain pour.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma-Mild malt and hops scent.  More corn and alcohol than anything else.  Not much to speak of.
Appearance-Standard lager clear golden color with a quickly disappating head.
Flavor-Why reproduce mass production style lager with a higher alcohol content?  idk but if this is what you are after than more power to you.
Palate-Bitter alcohol with metallic tones.
Overall-If you want to get drunk quick and you like the taste of the mass produced lagers this is the beer for you.  It is not the beer for me however.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 Off spoiled aroma in bottle but, in the glass it has a little sweetness added to the olfactory. Smell comes on with slight hints of strong ale. Ubiquitous pale yellow american lager appearance. Has the feel of pale lager with some above average whisky added. I frowned upon lion stout so I was not looking forward to trying this because the label looks just like lion stout. For 8%, you certainly can taste the alky but it is not very abrasive, not quite in the face. Has a recently manufactured plastic hose taste that comes and goes. I know this is in the pale lager style, but it is certainly a malt liquor. Cheap american malt liquor finish.  You know, the same as a strong ale but cheaper. Better than Lion Foreign  Stout.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a pale, golden color with no head to speak of.  Smells like sweet steel and alcohol.  Tastes metallic, hints of creamed corn and booze.  Thin and watery, avoid.

First of all this is not a normal pale lager, it is definitely a european strong laber style.  Pours a clear pale gold with minimal head.  Aroma sweet corn and malts.  Flavor very very alcoholy and abrasive, kinda reminding me of rubbing alcohol.  Drank this around a bonfire which was perfect setting for it.

Bottle, poured into a pint glass.  Pours light gold with a large creamy and frothy white head.  There is no lacing but the head does stick around for the whole beer.  Looking at the glass it is sparkling and very thin looking like a pale lager should look.  There is a slight grassy and citrusy aroma with a little alcohol aroma.  Takeing a taste there is a slight citrusy taste along with a hint of banana taste.  The body is light with a watery texture and lively carbonation.  In the finish:  There is a metallic finish along with a alcoholic finish.
Pours a fizzy yellow color without much head at all. Bananas and apples in the aroma. Very sweet tasting beer with a lot of apple juice. Surprisingly not offensive.
This pours a dark gold with a one finger head that fades quick. Has a bread-corn hint on the nose. Taste is different. Not much of a lager flavor, more of malt liquor? Finish is harsh and bitter.

The aroma was fruity with a grape note when first poured into the glass. A strong grape juice (like white grape juice) character dominated the aroma with wafts of strong alcohol. Some caramel lurked behind and a light bready character. In the glass the beer was crystal clear golden but lost all head in an instant and barely even traced at the glass. The flavor was malty and strong with alcohol. There could be no doubt that this beast is here and is going for your throat with the entire pride backing him up. Caramel and a lightly spicy hop nature was notable, but alcohol ruled the day. The body was medium full and with a low level of carbonation the beer was not creamy on the palate. The alcohol was notable in the aroma and flavor but was surprisingly restrained in the warming that came after consumption. Not my first choice for an Imperial Pils. 330 ml bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: So this imperial "thing" has carried over to Sri Lanka. Bring it on! Light golden color with a full off-white head. Dust malt and corn aromas. Hints of alcohol mix with the corn. The longer this one warms the worse it smells. Light floral sweetness couples with pale malt and light corn syrup. A somewhat sharp middle with a lightly acidic/acetic bite that carries to the finish and linger. Full bodied and sort of silky. Finish is simple and just has a grain induced light alcohol sweetness. A malt liquor by any other name...
Lighty skunk smell with a sweet honey color.  Very light watery taste with a little malt and hints of grain.
Much more of a malt liquor than a pale lager. Light adjunct filled aroma, and sweet corn and sugar flavor.  Very sweet for a pale lager.  Yellow.
Strong corn aroma.  Golden colored body with a true white head.  Some faint hops come through.  I would compare this to a good malt liquor.  But IMO its really hard to do much with that style.

Pours a bubbly golden hue.  Very biscuity aroma with hints of caramel like sweetness.  The flavor is slightly sweet with a nice earthy grainyness to it.  The mouthfeel is a little watery, but the balance is dead on.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: No aroma. Taste is mostly sweet and alcohol. Fairly thick mouth feel. Wouldnt buy again.

Bottle. Poured clear golden color with a large white frothy head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate sweet grassy aroma. Medium body with soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration with no alcohol bite.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 Pours golden yellow/pale, transparent with a big white head.  Definitely filtered.  Very smooth body, crisp taste, sweet flavor immediately, cotton candy, very mild hop bitterness, good carbonation.  Alcohol is present for sure.  Would be a nice warm weather beer as it is refreshing, but not watered down.
